practices.description: Evaluation using situations, tasks, or standards similar to those that professionals usually face.
Engaging students in complex and authentic tasks that foster the development of practical skills under faculty supervision.
Encouraging students to evaluate their own work, promoting reflection and self-awareness in learning.
Designing curriculum activities that support the achievement of objectives and reflect assessments.
Providing timely and high-quality feedback to help students understand their progress and areas for improvement.
Encouraging students to apply what they have learned in increasingly authentic, real-world contexts and/or in real-world-like problems.

latent_traits.trait: Fostering an emotional connection with content

practices.description: Engaging students by stimulating their interest in course material to foster better learning outcomes.

practices.practice: Relating Content to Students’ Lives and Interests
practices.description: Highlighting how new content connects with students’ personal contexts to facilitate integration with prior knowledge.
Demonstrating enthusiasm for the course or content to inspire students and create a positive learning environment.
Teacher availability and willingness to help students or answer questions.
Ensure that the course content is delivered clearly and understandably to improve student learning.
Allowing students to witness problem-solving or reasoning so that thought processes, planning, or approaches become explicit.
Class visual resources (such as presentations or others) are understandable and facilitate content comprehension.
Faculty use the same teaching-learning activities repeatedly or for a long-time within the lesson.
The course content, activities, or assignments do not present an interesting challenge for the students, their level of knowledge, and their skills.

practices.practice: No validation of assessment and grades
practices.description: There are no attempts to learn about and improve the criteria-based quality of assessments and resulting grading.
The presentation of the content or assessment activities (e.g., assignments) does not match the students’ level of knowledge and skills.
There are no activities which monitor, analyze, and regulate the learners’ knowledge and skill developments.
There are no activities which demonstrate how to perform desired activities or which articulate the reasoning necessary for the activities.
The learning objectives omit relevant areas or, conversely, cover too many aspects to be manageable.
There is no clear structure on contents, activities, or in time.
